Sir, I much regret to inform you that this morning sixty six people were killed and about fifty people were injured, some of them seriously,at the house of Mohammed Tayeb Kiiunji, a Persian ( Sunni ) merchant of Manama. Most of the people concerned were women. 2. -— A crov/d of about two thousand persons from Budeya, Iledd and Rafaa, as well as from Manama and Muharraq, collected at the house of Mohammed Tayeb this morning hearing that he was going to give alms to the poor. There was no organisation and crowds of people pressed in through the main door and filled the compound. Between the door and the compound there is a narrow passage about fifteen feet long. One of Mohammed Tayeb ! s sons, seeing that the compound and the passage were full and people were pushing eachother about, went outside the door, in the road, and called out that the money would be distributed in another building across the street. People inside heard this and began to surge out through the passage. It seems that someone else at the same time gave orders ior bne outer door to be shut to prevent more people coming in. The door, which opened inwards, was shut and locked. The narrow passage 1 was filled with a solid mass of people and others, from the compound, forced their way into the passage. There was no air and no light. As more people crowded in those inside were forced against the door, they struggled and fought and were forced down to the ground and trampled on bythe incoming crowds. There were about two hundred people in the passage. An eyewitness described them as being heaped one on top of the other four deep like bags of rice. Some of them were old and there were children among them. For a long time it was impossible to enter the passage or to move anyoody but eventually people were sent to neighbouring houses to get ropes and crow bars and then the door was. smashed open. When this was done it was possible to carry out the people, but most of them were dead. The greater proportion died from suffocation. Wnen I arrived the bodies were being taken out and spread in the road and in the compound of the house. Unfortunately all the Police and naturs were occupied with the Muharram procession. For s some time it was impossible to do much to relieve the people who needed attention, there were crowds outside and inside the house.^ Eventually the people were cleared out and some of the Police arrived. Dr Holmes and the two Mission doctors dealt with the cases. Some of the staff of the Bahrain Petroleum Company who happened to be in the neighbourhood came and helped with the rescue work and produced two motor lorries on which bodies and injured people were carried to the hospital. These gentlemen were of very great assistance. 5. I do not think that anyone v/as uirectly to blame for the disaster,it was entirely owing to lack of arganisation. Two days ago Mohammed Tayeb 1 s son asked his father not to distribute alms in this way but Mohammed Tayeb refused to make other arrangements. Two years ago there was a similar incident in the same house but there were no deaths and nobody was seriously injured.I iKp GOVERNMENT OF BAHRAIN. 6 Six of the victims were Shia ana the rest were Sunni. In the afternoon when the victims were being buried in the Sunni cemetery there was a demonstration by a large crowd of Shias who jeered at the mourners and cried out that this was the vengeance of Hussein, The Shias have for some time resented Mohammed TayeVs habit of giving alms on what is to tnem a day of mourning. I think that a public enquiry should be held in order to check the rumours which will undoubtedly be spread about the matter not only in Bahrain but abroad. The owner of the house is a foreigner and many of the victims are foreign subjects. It might be advisable to appoint a mixed committee to examine and report on the affair. 7 I have the honour to be Sir Your obedient servant Adviser to the Bahrain GovernmentGOVERNMENT OF BAHRAIN. titleInfo.title: 'File 6/66 Correspondence regarding casualties reported at the house of Haji Muhammad Tayib Kunji - a Persian merchant of Manamah - during distribution of alms on the 10th Muharram/14th April 1935'

physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 81; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-75; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence concerning an incident on 14 April 1935 which resulted in the deaths of at least 75 people due to crushing and suffocation. The incident occurred at the home of the Persian merchant Mohammed Tayeb Khunji, where a crowd had gathered to receive alms. The correspondence is mostly from the Political Agency in Bahrain, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Lieutenant-Colonel Trenchard Craven William Fowle), and Adviser to the Government of Bahrain (Charles Dalrymple Belgrave).The file contains the following:letters of sympathy (sent through the Political Agency) from numerous British political, diplomatic, and military offices in the region, including the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf, Secretary of State for India and the Minister in Tehran;letters of thanks (also sent through the Political Agency) from Shaikh Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifah [Shaikh Ḥamad bin ‘Īsá Āl Khalīfah] in reply to letters of sympathy;correspondence discussing what official account of the incident should be given and from what source;correspondence and public notices relating to a public enquiry into the incident;correspondence concerning donations to a fund for the families of the victims, including a list (in Arabic) of all donors and the amounts donated (folios 61-71);several newspaper cuttings of articles about the incident from the British press (folios 56-58 and 74).Folios 76-80 are internal office notes.
